Compadres across from the resort is about the only restaurant you can walk to, but they had good food and some great drink specials. One thing that was strange....We had a two bedroom unit and the second bedroom was across the deck in another trailer. Close, yes, but we weren't comfortable putting our two year old over there even with the baby monitor we brought with us. However, the second bedroom was a studio unit and would have been great if we had brought a second couple instead of our two year old (Next time....) Overall, a wonderful vacation spot.

Reviews.Title: “Fun Time, Great Location”
Reviews.Author: bob ashdown
Reviews.Content: We enjoyed our stay at River Pointe, arranged through a time share exchange with Interval International. It is an excellent location to explore the wine country or to take day trips into San Francisco, Sacramento, or along the coast. Our unit was small, but comfortable and charming. Staff members are friendly and helpful, as were the other guests we met. If staying in a mobile home in close proximity to other guests is not your thing, then I suggest you look elsewhere for accommodations. Our one-bedroom unit, spacious enough for the two of us, would have been crowded for four. Opening our windows for fresh air also let in the voices of other guests and we could hear others when we sat on our deck. It was not a problem for us, but it could be for someone who desires privacy and quiet. Our positive experience with the staff began when I called in advance for information about wine tours. During that conversation as well as subsequent ones at the resort, the staff provided information and suggestions that enhanced our stay. Maintenance handled the one issue we had, a light bulb change, within minutes. Our unit was cleaned midweek and new towels were provided and trash removed two additional times. Our unit had a comfortable bed and living area, a table large enough for the two of us to dine, a microwave with a convection oven, two burners, a large refrigerator, and a deck with an unusually large table with four chairs. We didnâ€™t use the pool, but did enjoy a conveniently located hot tub. The workout room had only three pieces of equipment, but we exercised by walking on a beautiful 1.2 mile path along the Napa River. The staff includes a two-page list of activities in the registration packet. We recommend attending the resort-hosted orientation, a complete hot breakfast, as well as one or both of the complementary onsite wine tastings. We took the wine tour which includes tasting at four wineries, tours at three of them, and a delicious picnic lunch for $70 per person. Tours of San Francisco and the Napa River also are offered but we passed on them. The marketing person who gave us our parking pass also provided a map of the area wineries, a brochure that includes tasting coupons, and suggestions for interesting wineries to visit. She also suggested that we consider sharing a tasting, rather than pay for two tastings, at each winery. Sharing allowed us to taste safely at more wineries. You will find a Wal Mart near River Pointe as well as a Safeway, Trader Joeâ€™s, and a Whole Food Market within short driving distances. A Farmerâ€™s Market in town offers fresh produce as well as local bakery products.

Reviews.Title: “Really nice little place....”
Reviews.Author: hcapelle
Reviews.Content: My husband and I spent a week at the Riverpointe Napa Valley resort. We traded our timeshare week through Interval International. I had read some unpleasant reviews, but we really wanted to go to Napa, so we took our chance. We loved it. I mean it's not the Villagio Spa in Yountville--but it was clean and nice and more than fine for what we needed. You could walk to Copia or the Wine Train in about 20 minutes. The staff was always very accommodating. They even gave us the Founders Room so we could have internet in our unit. It was quiet and cozy. I would definitely stay there again!

Reviews.Title: “Give it a try!! especially with other hotel $$”
Reviews.Author: suwood
Reviews.Content: Great time! yes, yes, we too thought wow! it's a trailor? (we frequent luxury hotels often- but pay much more$$) Once you get past the outside features... it is super clean, homey,comfortable, VERY close to everything!! Everyone was VERY friendly- employees and guests. We felt like they totally took care of us and wrote out special itineraries to meet our needs! We felt like we were part of a special "club" and participated in all thier activities- complimentary wine tastings, shuttled wine tour, etc.. We say, give it a try!! can't beat the price and location!! spend $$ on food, wine and attractions! We will definately be back and I might just go back for a "girlfriends trip"!!

Reviews.Title: “ok stay”
Reviews.Author: rockesfans
Reviews.Content: We atayed at River point for a week in May on a timeshare trade. We knew they were trailors but went for the locations. Unfortunately if you are there during a hear wave, which we were, the air conditioning units are very loud. The washers and dryers are in an outdoor shed, and very hot. The staff was very helpful. When we checked in we were surprised with added charges due to rising costs. Never had thta happen before. We really had no choice but to pay up. Only $40.00 or so plus maid tips.,I guess it was the point of surprise charges that we didnt like. Because it was so hot we really couldnt use the patio. The trailor becaome quite small by the end of the week. All in all, relatively inexpensive stay in Napa.

Reviews.Title: “Not worth the money!”
Reviews.Author: AvengerCalifornia
Reviews.Content: My husband, daughter and I visited River Pointe for the weekend. Upon arrival we discovered that the plush accommodations, were 'trailers" "mobile homes" The staff was rude not accommodating at all. Questions we asked we were never given the correct information and the staff, seemed bothered by our questions. i.e. where is a good place to eat, shop etc....The first night one of the guests had a party, LOUD and to boot, the resort was hosting a party, not sure if it was a wedding reception or what, but it was LOUD and the party goer's were loud and obnoxious! Eventually, we phoned the front desk to complain. This went on to about 1:30 AM eventually the local police department were called to break up the crowd. Needless to say, it was a sleepless night! It is a complete waste of money and the value you are getting is zilch! I'd rate this resort "one star" Also, the pool didn't seem very clean. Left an odd residue on your skin. We haven't returned to River Pointe and will never return. I guess, all I can say is, if you are interested in renting for the weekend or what not, "take your chances" There are some reviews on here about being so pleased etc...Quite surprising to me!!! We were NOT pleased!!!

Reviews.Title: “Charming Place by the River”
Reviews.Author: mini
Reviews.Content: I liked the location of the Riverpointe in Napa Valley. It is right by the river and quite enjoyable stay. I had read the Trip Advisor reviews in advance of others who had stayed there and it immediately helped us to have a great time. We loved the "very very upscale travel trailer home" experience. The decor was lovely; the beds were comfy; the outdoor decks fabulous. We enjoyed being able to take a quick walk to the wonderful river walk by the river. The swimming pool, sauna, and club house are TOP NOTCH. Simply wonderful. We also enjoyed doing our own barbecue one night - they have top of the line barbecues. We will be back sometime. The location to drive to the wineries is ideal. If you are a time share exchange person (we were), its a great exchange for a week stay. If bookinng for a few nights, just realize you are getting a nice homey experience. The 5 stars were from Interval International, which is the time share exchange. Definitely this property is worth 5 stars for a time share; it is not 5 stars if you are looking for a luxury hotel. All in all, however, its great.

Reviews.Title: “It grew on us and makes us want to return”
Reviews.Author: joyceg
Reviews.Content: Wanting to stay in Napa for a week, we traded our timeshare for the RiverPointe Napa Valley (which also is a hotel). Like most places in wine country, the location was fine as long as you have a car. But it is just a short distance to the Silverarado Trail as well as close to the town of Napa. Upon checkin, we initial wondered what we got ourselves in to. These are "trailers" that can be moved in case of a flood (this is the only way the property could build on the location which is prone to floading). The last flood was 2005 so we didn't see this as a big problem (and the property makes this point very clear that you may have to vacate within 2 hours). The checkin area looked OK and the front desk staff person was informative. Still, we had a little queazy feeling in our stomachs as we drove to our small "trailer". Upon walking in, we quickly surveyed the small space. The "kitchen" has a full size refrigerator, 2 burners, a sink, dishwasher and microwave. The trash can didn't quite fit in the cabinet due to the fire extinguisher. Since they had regular trash pickup, they could have used a smaller trash can. But, as long as you look upon the kitchen as a place for breakfast and snacks, you are fine. I wouldn't want to cook dinner here however, with all of the wonderful restaurants--particularly in Yountville and St. Helena--why cook? The kitchen was in one corner of the living room area, which also included a small breakfast table (which has leaves that you can pull up to make it larger, a 3 person sleeper couch and a chair. The couch is firm but very comfortable. The TV area has the normal DVD, CD etc components and worked well. Bathroom was somewhat normal with a tub/shower (not huge, but adequate). The place had some nice closet space. We asked for a king bed and had to take turns walking around the bed. The bedroom also has a desk in it with chairs. However, we had to move the chairs so that we could walk around the bed. For the first day, we kept saying to ourselves that we would be OK in the small space, and if not, we could always go home to San Francisco. However, we grew to like the place and actually looked at dates to return. Why? Everything was very clean and maintained. The towels were nice and fluffy--way above what I would have expected in a place like this. The bed was very comfortable once we asked for (and quickly got) less firm pillows. The concierge had put together some good programs to acquaint people with the area and the resort. There was an orientation breakfast where she spoke to all the different types of travellers in the audience, plus 2 wine tastings...all free). She had printed out coupons for wine tastings and schedules of what was happening in the valley while we were there. The staff was well trained and very responsive. Even the person who came in daily to pick up trash and give us fresh towels was very pleasant. My only negatives are very minor. The resort tacked on a $5/day resort fee which allows you free laundry and some other stuff that few people use but that the properties use to justify extra cost. I personally think these kinds of fees are rarely justified and believe they should be included. in the nightly pricing. Yes, it did include wireless access in the lobby...duhhhhhh..wireless is SOP in many places now. Maybe it was to pay for the nice working area they had set aside in the lobby building..whatever. The wireless was only in the lobby building. Since we were paying $5/day for it, I would have liked it in our trailers too. I suspect this is a logistical problem as the trailers are spread out and...well, they are movable trailers. If you had a dial up (does anyone have those anymore?) connection, you could use it in your trailer. They also rented DVDs for $3 each or $10 for your stay. Why couldn't this be part of the $5/day fee? Can you tell that I bristle at extra fees? The only other negative was that the blanket didn't quite fit the bed. This was a very minor issue however. Once we turned it 45 degrees, we were fine. Bottom line, it turned out to be a pleasant stay in spite of our initial apprehension. While we tend to like something a little more upscale, in pricy Napa, is it a very good compromise and we are likely to return. Just be away that you may be required to vacate during the rainy season.

Reviews.Title: “We Enjoyed Our Stay & Will Go Back Someday”
Reviews.Author: thdzsm
Reviews.Content: We just returned from River Point. Yes, it is not a 5 Star Resort. However, it is a small and friendly 3 Star Resort. The cottages are actually relatively small trailers and you will feel some movement as you walk across the floor. However, my wife and I really enjoyed our stay. The other guests were exceptionally friendly and the staff was helpful and informative. The Resort arranged winery tours and other group excursions. The location is great. We rode our bikes to old downtown Napa and along the Silverado Trail. Dining was GREAT! World class restaurants are located just minuets from the resort. The 5 Star Rating sets high expectations which this resort simply canâ€™t achieve. We usually stay at 5 Star Resorts and enjoy all of the amenities. Nevertheless, we really enjoyed our trip to River Point in Napa and plan to return someday.

Reviews.Title: “Charming River Resort”
Reviews.Author: WanderingSu2
Reviews.Content: I don't usually write reviews but I was in the process of recommending this timeshare resort to a friend back east and saw the terrible review written before this one. I have stayed there twice - once for a week in May 2007 on a timeshare trade and once for two nights in August 2007 just for fun! The "cottages" are charming - they are little cottage trailers with decks - when the river reaches flood stage, they can pull them off the property - seems smart to me! The cottages have a living room, eating area, kitchen with dishwasher, range top, garbage disposal and full sized refrigerator. There is a big bathroom and either a king or queen bed. The queen bed fits better as the room is small around the king - which we did have for our week stay. It's convenient and clean and nice. I didn't love the desk crew on the second visit and we found that using Resortime.com was more expensive than calling directly for the two night stay, but I would stay there again - and I would call directly.

Reviews.Title: “We're Already Planning Another Trip!”
Reviews.Author: Retiredbarnqueen
Reviews.Content: It's a great place to stay. Comfortable, convenient, and very friendly. We've been to so many places where you don't meet anyone, but the people who come to River Pointe have common ground: wine. You talk in the pool, hot tub, in the club house, or on the street. You exchange tips where to go, and where not to go (not too many of those). You get lots of help from the front desk, as well as the concierge. (She has coupons for free tastings.) They even arrange for your wine shipments! River Pointe was quiet, comfortable, conveniently located, and very, very friendly. Don't be dismayed by the 'trailer' talk. You'd hardly know you were in one!

Reviews.Title: “I'ts a glorified trailer park ”
Reviews.Author: luv2travel015
Reviews.Content: We just spent 1 week at this "resort." This place is not at all what it appears to be. It is not a 5* resort as we were told. It is a glorified trailer park - really! Beneath the white lattice surrounding each unit are a trailer hitch, and wheels. The units are tiny. We booked a 2-bedroom unit, and one of the bedrooms and baths was in a different trailer. They expect you to do their inventory of kitchen items at the end of your stay. They could not provide a separate cot, even though the unit is supposed to sleep 6 - there was actually no room for one. The units are not very clean - just passable. Don't look in the corners. Also, the housekeeping leaves much to be desired. They only do a "mini-clean" midweek - not much cleaning really. They change the beds and towels. You have to beg for bath tissue - they only give you 1 roll at a time. The pool was not heated, and dirty. Yes, you do need a heated pool in Napa - nights and mornings are quite cold. If you're going to Napa, stay at another hotel, or better yet, in Sonoma. This place is not cheap, and we expected more than a trailer park when we booked.

Reviews.Title: “Great Resort, BUT”
Reviews.Author: Jane80
Reviews.Content: River Pointe is a charming, well kept resort. The cottages are trailers, with wheels still attached, so you get a little "movement" when someone is walking. Overall, we had a great time. The staff was helpful and informative. The location is great, close to old downtown Napa and the Silverado Trail to the wineries. The resort had a wine tasting and gave good tips. This would have been a near perfect vacation except: during our week's stay they had booked two events, weddings I think, that took place around the Clubhouse. Both had blaring, really loud music playing on loudspeakers. One event happened all 4th of July so I overlooked it. The other was a Saturday night and the music and DJ could be heard until midnight! It was impossible to get to sleep before that so I left very tired! If you want a quiet relaxing time be sure to ask when you book if they have any "parties" planned. That is the only thing that would prevent me from returning.

Reviews.Title: “Great "base camp" for your visit to Wine Country”
Reviews.Author: Namgrunt
Reviews.Content: We booked our week via Interval International using a trade from our "home resort" of Swallowtail (Hilton Head Island.) Riverpoint is a classic timeshare. It is a small, cozy resort -- not the glitzy mega-resorts that are now the trend. As were some others, I was a bit apprehensive about Riverpointe; however, I was pleasantly surprised. Accomodations are mobile homes -- somewhat small, but clean and very effective as a "base" for exploring Napa, all of Wine Country, and the coastal areas like Point Reyes. Location is great -- turn right and you are in downtown Napa -- turn left and you are on the Silverado Trail.

Reviews.Title: “Really cool place to stay in Napa Valley”
Reviews.Author: bmesservy
Reviews.Content: My husband's clients gave us a week of their timeshare here, and we loved every minute of it. If you've read the reviews of River Pointe, you know that the "units" are in fact trailers. Don't be alarmed! True, the units are mobile homes, but they are amazing!! We had a one bedroom, one bath (pics uploaded), and it was the perfect size for the 2 of us for a whole week. We want one just like it to stay in when we visit his parents' lake place. There is a bedroom, full bath (larger than any hotel bath i've seen), a kitchen area, a family room with pullout couch, and a porch with a 4-seater table. The kitchen does not have a regular oven, which we found out after we bought a frozen pizza to cook. It only has a convection oven/microwave. But everything else that you need is there! Laundry room in the back of the complex. Only 4 washers and 4 dryers, so do your laundry when you don't expect anyone else to. We went at the end of April, during the first phase of the growing season in the wineries, so it was pretty quiet. The resort does have a "quiet policy" from 9pm-9am, so neighbors disturbing you are never a problem. DON'T BRING YOUR PETS ON THE PROPERTY. They clearly tell you this, but our neighbors apparently couldn't read. They brought their little dog, and the people at the resort told them they had to leave. The only time that I was not happy was when one of the guest services people (Marilyn) never called me back after I left 3 messages for her. I was trying to book my husband and I on a special expedition through the wineries through the resort, and due to the fact that she never called back, we were not signed up for the Saturday tour. She had to create a Sunday tour to get us in, but when the other couples who were scheduled for Sunday cancelled, she never even called us to let us know. My husband had gone up to the front desk to ask about something else, and Marilyn said, "Oh yeah, we can't drive you around today." Everything worked out, though....we just drove ourselves and covered two times the wineries the resort would have covered. Anyway, I do recommend River Pointe Napa Valley. It is very convenient to everything in the Napa Valley region, as well as to Sonoma.

Reviews.Title: “Winter Time in Napa”
Reviews.Author: thechief71
Reviews.Content: We received our stay here from my parents who gave us their use of a timeshare. I have to admit that the website for the place makes it appear much "grander" than it really is. That being said, it's a nice place and I'm sure it's even prettier in the spring and summer. We stayed 4 nights. The clubhouse area and attendants are very pleaseant and quite helpful. We got lots of good tips for where to go and what to do. The accommodations though were just average. They are trailers with very nice inside decor. We definitely liked the "condo" type setting for a base of operation in the Napa Valley. Had I paid for a 4 stary type setting, I'd have been dissappointed. Nice place though.

Reviews.Title: “Scared by the "free standing trailers"...now going back again!”
Reviews.Author: lamccammon
Reviews.Content: I booked this through Interval International in 2004, with 3 of my girlfiriends, and was nervous when I got my paperwork that read: Please note: these units are free standing trailers. I couldn't believe I had booked myself and my friends at a trailer park! Once we got there, we were delighted by the bright, cheery and comfortable decor, our personal deck, the river that meanders through the property, the walking trail, and the convenience of location and being able to prepare some meals (namely breakfast) in our unit. I personally prefer the condo style to a stuffy hotel room, anyway. The staff was very informed and helpful with directions and recommendations. This year, my sister and I will be returning to River Pointe Napa Valley, and I am very much looking forward to it. That said, my total cost for 1 week was ~$500, so for a time share exchange, I was very pleased. If I were paying $150+/night, I might choose to stay somewhere else.

Reviews.Title: “More like a 3*”
Reviews.Author: 721belmont
Reviews.Content: This stay was an Interval exchange. Interval rate this resort as a 5*. I wouldn't. That being said, it was still an enjoyable stay. We had a two bedroom unit for 2 couples. This consisted of the main unit (which is basically a single wide small trailer) which had a living area, kitchen, bathroom (with tub) and bedroom. This unit was connected via an outside deck to the studio unit, which consisted of studio unit with bathroom (stand up shower). We all flinched when we first drove up because all the "cottages" were really packed in there, but after being there for a week, we hardly ever encountered other guests. They have the cottages arranged so you park and proceed to your deck. My biggest complaint is about the beds and pillows. They were terrible. The towels were plush, the furnishings were good, but the beds were awful! As I said, it is more like a 3*.

Reviews.Title: “Real Nice”
Reviews.Author: johnfasc
Reviews.Content: We stayed four nites with two other couples. Our rooms were located next to each other divided by a deck which was nice. The rooms were clean and comfortable. It was a nice centrally located motel. We did not partake of the time share sales event so that may be why we liked it. (We did listen to the group spiel). I would go back if not only that it is clean and in a nice location.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location for Napa Visit”
Reviews.Author: valibrn
Reviews.Content: Yes, the units are trailers! However, this is a great location for visiting Napa and Sonoma. The unit was clean, well-stocked, quiet, and comfortable, if a bit small. The resort itself is pleasant, with responsive and courteous staff. Our unit was bright and airy, with plenty of good quality towels and other linens. A cracked plate was replaced almost immediately. We've been in more luxurious resorts that weren't as clean and well-tended. Like in real estate, location is everything; the River Pointe makes visiting Napa Valley, Sonoma, Santa Rosa, San Francisco, Marin County, and other Bay area attractions easy.

Reviews.Title: “Glorified trailer park”
Reviews.Author: keepntabs
Reviews.Content: I toured the River Pointe "resort" on 8/11/06, and all I can say is what a waste of time. The salesperson started off with the typical chit-chat about what kind of work I do, yaddah-yaddah-yaddah. They offered some generic cookies, coffee, and cups of water. I truly went there with an open mind to buy, because I wanted a holiday spot that was somewhat close to home, but this certainly wasn't it. The cabins are very small trailers (the one-bedroom has to be about 300 s.f.) with wood paneling to disguise them, and the whole place is located in a flood plan. Last winter guests had to be evacuated, because the heavy rains flooded the area (and they had to repair their cot-trailers). If you are familiar with No. Cal. you know that just about any winter can have a heavy rain season. The kitchens do not have ovens, just a stovetop and microwave. Although the couch does pull out, if you scoot to the bottom of the sofabed you will be able to open the front door without having to stand up. There is about 18" walking perimeter around the bed. The studio units are just bedrooms with a bathroom, and mini-fridge. The site does not provide views of any wineries, because it is in downtown Napa (which is not quaint like downtown Sonoma) off of a major street. The only amenities that are on site are a small gym, lap pool, and two jacuzzis. There is no tennis court, spa, restaurant, bar, golf, volleyball, walking trail...not even a pingpong table. When I asked about the lack of amenities, I was told that they would increase the maintenance fee (which is about $570 per year). This was really an unsatifactory answer, because I own another timeshare, and have seen others that charge less and are capable of having these types of amenities onsite for their members. The salesperson kept emphasizing the "benefit" of being able to trade your timeshare via Interval and other trading companies, or visiting one of their sister resorts. He didn't go into great detail about having to pay another membership to these companies ($80-90 per year), or how much more you it costs to trade ($50-150). So I got the impression that they know that most locals won't want to stay their, but wish to use the timeshare as a means to have access to other more desirable timeshares. So forget about having a nice getaway place that is only an hour's drive, because you will still have to drive to anything that's worth doing (gas costs $3.25 per gallon for regular unleaded). Another benefit is that a member can use the facilities anytime during the day, and I can tell there was a great demand for this added bonus by the four women I saw by the pool/jacuzzis. Lastly, I was told what an "asset" buying a timeshare there would be instead of spending money on hotels. Well, when I buy an asset I expect it to appreciate in value. I asked him to tell me what is the historical re-sale value of the timeshares during the 8 years they've existed. He got his manager to try to answer that question, and he could only tell me that a 2bd/2ba annual visit cost $22,500 in 1998, and the same unit was going for $28,675 today (FYI, an every other year 1 bedroom costs $9500+ now). This is about a 22% increase during a period where real estate values in the area have appreciated between 400-500%. . So the long and short of it is, buy a timeshare at River Pointe if: you don't want to stay there yourself; you want to rent a car (or have to drive) and spend a small fortune in gas, because nothing is close by (except Walmart); you don't mind staying in extremely cramped space that may flood in the winter or catch fire during the summer, and you prefer to spend your money on something that you will probably won't use, and have to spend more to get to a real resort (where you wish you had actually bought). The salesperson wasn't too pushy, but you can't get your gifts without one last pitch from the Trading Places (the other timeshare trading company) salesperson. I received a $25 gift certificate to Macy's, a travel certificate for 3 days/2 nights travel to either Las Vegas, New Orleans, Orlando, Cancun or Jamaica (these last two incur an additional charge of $169), and an invitation for a wine tour (which is dumb, because many wineries give free wine tours daily). By the rules of the travel certificate, the earliest that I can actually travel will January 2007, and the certificate is only good for a year from the date of issue. Spend your money and time at a nice B&B in the Napa Valley. You'll feel much better, and be getting more bang for your buck.

Reviews.Title: “Horrible Timeshare Value!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I visited the River Pointe Napa Valley Resort to participate in a timeshare presentation. Having visited a couple of other international timeshare presentations and coming very close to actually buying one, we were very excited about the prospect of owning locally while still having access to exotic locations worldwide. Well this "resort" was a far cry from the real vacation getaways we've toured before (imagine having a Walmart and the train tracks across the street from your 5-star timeshare). Not only were we subjected to over 1.5 hours of verbal abuse from an obviously disgruntled â€œfriendly and professionalâ€� sales consultant, but we never actually got to see the rooms or the grounds since they apparently werenâ€™t important to the value-building portion of the timeshare presentation. We did, however, get a glimpse of the bedroom sized fitness center located behind the bathrooms in the main lobby. In closing, if your idea of a 5-star resort is one that treats their prospective owners on a 90+ degree day to a Â½ cup of tepid water and a stale cookie while being seated on your standard elementary school style chairs, then this might just be the place for you. Needless to say, we were not impressed and chose not to waste our money on a company that could exercise such poor judgment in choosing their representatives.
